articles.title: Le futur en allemand : faire des projets ensemble
articles.content:
import VocabCard from '@components/VocabCard.astro';
import ConjugationTable from '@components/ConjugationTable.astro';
import CultureTip from '@components/CultureTip.astro';
import PhraseOfDay from '@components/PhraseOfDay.astro';
import CTA from '@components/CTA.astro';

R√™ver ensemble de l'avenir est l'une des joies d'√™tre en couple. Que vous planifiez vos prochaines vacances, votre mariage ou simplement le d√Æner de demain, savoir exprimer le futur en allemand vous permettra de partager vos espoirs et projets avec votre partenaire.

## Bonne nouvelle : l'allemand simplifie le futur !

En allemand, on utilise tr√®s souvent le **pr√©sent** avec un indicateur de temps futur pour parler de l'avenir. C'est beaucoup plus simple qu'en fran√ßais !

<VocabCard
  word="Morgen gehen wir ins Kino"
  translation="Demain nous allons au cin√©ma"
  pronunciation="[MOR-gueune GU√â-eune vir inss KI-no]"
  example="Morgen gehen wir zusammen ins Kino, oder?"
/>

### Le pr√©sent pour le futur

| Allemand | Fran√ßais | Explication |
|----------|----------|-------------|
| Ich komme morgen | Je viens demain | Pr√©sent + indicateur temps |
| N√§chstes Jahr heiraten wir | L'ann√©e prochaine nous nous marions | Pr√©sent + indicateur temps |
| Am Wochenende fahren wir weg | Ce week-end nous partons | Pr√©sent + indicateur temps |

<CultureTip title="Usage naturel" flag="üá©üá™">
Dans la vie quotidienne, les Allemands utilisent le pr√©sent pour le futur dans environ 80% des cas. Si vous dites "Ich werde morgen kommen" au lieu de "Ich komme morgen", vous sonnez un peu formel, mais c'est parfaitement correct !
</CultureTip>

## Le futur avec ¬´ werden ¬ª

Pour les projets plus lointains, les promesses solennelles ou quand vous voulez insister sur le futur, utilisez **werden** + infinitif.

<ConjugationTable
  verb="werden"
  meaning="devenir / auxiliaire du futur"
  conjugations={[
    { "person": "ich", "word": "werde", "translation": "je vais / je serai" },
    { "person": "du", "word": "wirst", "translation": "tu vas / tu seras" },
    { "person": "er/sie/es", "word": "wird", "translation": "il/elle va / sera" },
    { "person": "wir", "word": "werden", "translation": "nous allons / serons" },
    { "person": "ihr", "word": "werdet", "translation": "vous allez / serez" },
    { "person": "sie/Sie", "word": "werden", "translation": "ils/elles vont / seront" }
  ]}
/>

### Structure de la phrase au futur

**Sujet + werden (conjugu√©) + ... + infinitif (√† la fin)**

<PhraseOfDay
  word="Ich werde dich immer lieben"
  translation="Je t'aimerai toujours"
  pronunciation="[ich V√àR-deu dich I-meur LI-beune]"
  context="La promesse romantique ultime √† faire √† votre partenaire"
/>

### Exemples de projets de couple

- **Wir werden zusammen alt werden** [vir V√àR-deune tsou-ZA-meune alt V√àR-deune] - Nous vieillirons ensemble
- **Du wirst meine Frau werden** [dou virst MA√è-neu fraou V√àR-deune] - Tu deviendras ma femme
- **Ich werde dich nie verlassen** [ich V√àR-deu dich ni f√®r-LA-sseune] - Je ne te quitterai jamais
- **Wir werden gl√ºcklich sein** [vir V√àR-deune GLUK-lich za√Øne] - Nous serons heureux

## Indicateurs de temps pour le futur

Ma√Ætrisez ces expressions pour situer vos projets dans le temps :

<VocabCard
  word="in Zukunft"
  translation="√† l'avenir"
  pronunciation="[ine TSOU-kounft]"
  example="In Zukunft werden wir mehr reisen."
/>

### Vocabulaire temporel essentiel

| Allemand | Fran√ßais | Prononciation |
|----------|----------|---------------|
| morgen | demain | [MOR-gueune] |
| √ºbermorgen | apr√®s-demain | [U-beur-mor-gueune] |
| n√§chste Woche | la semaine prochaine | [N√àKS-teu VO-cheu] |
| n√§chsten Monat | le mois prochain | [N√àKS-teune MO-nat] |
| n√§chstes Jahr | l'ann√©e prochaine | [N√àKS-tess yar] |
| bald | bient√¥t | [balt] |
| sp√§ter | plus tard | [CHP√à-teur] |
| eines Tages | un jour | [A√è-ness TA-guess] |
| irgendwann | un jour (ind√©fini) | [IR-guent-vanne] |

## Faire des projets concrets ensemble

### Planifier un voyage

<VocabCard
  word="Wohin werden wir reisen?"
  translation="O√π allons-nous voyager ?"
  pronunciation="[vo-HINE V√àR-deune vir RA√è-zeune]"
  example="Wohin werden wir in den Flitterwochen reisen?"
/>

**Phrases utiles pour planifier :**

- **N√§chsten Sommer fahren wir ans Meer** - L'√©t√© prochain nous allons √† la mer
- **Wir werden zwei Wochen in Italien verbringen** - Nous passerons deux semaines en Italie
- **Ich m√∂chte mit dir die Welt sehen** - Je voudrais voir le monde avec toi
- **Lass uns zusammen nach Deutschland reisen** - Partons ensemble en Allemagne

### Projets de vie √† deux

| Projet | Allemand | Prononciation |
|--------|----------|---------------|
| Emm√©nager ensemble | zusammenziehen | [tsou-ZA-meune-tsi-eune] |
| Se fiancer | sich verloben | [zich f√®r-LO-beune] |
| Se marier | heiraten | [HA√èE-ra-teune] |
| Avoir des enfants | Kinder bekommen | [KIN-deur beu-KO-meune] |
| Acheter une maison | ein Haus kaufen | [a√Øne haous KAOU-feune] |

<CultureTip title="Tradition allemande" flag="üá©üá™">
En Allemagne, beaucoup de couples emm√©nagent ensemble longtemps avant de se marier. L'expression "Wir ziehen zusammen" (nous emm√©nageons ensemble) est une √©tape importante, souvent annonc√©e officiellement √† la famille et aux amis.
</CultureTip>

## Exprimer des souhaits et des r√™ves

Pour parler de vos r√™ves de couple, combinez le futur avec des verbes de souhait :

<VocabCard
  word="Ich hoffe, dass wir"
  translation="J'esp√®re que nous"
  pronunciation="[ich HO-feu, dass vir]"
  example="Ich hoffe, dass wir immer so gl√ºcklich sein werden."
/>

### Verbes pour exprimer des souhaits

- **hoffen** [HO-feune] - esp√©rer
- **w√ºnschen** [VUN-cheune] - souhaiter
- **tr√§umen von** [TROE-meune fone] - r√™ver de
- **planen** [PLA-neune] - planifier
- **vorhaben** [FOR-ha-beune] - avoir l'intention de

### Phrases pour partager vos r√™ves

- **Ich tr√§ume davon, mit dir alt zu werden** - Je r√™ve de vieillir avec toi
- **Wir planen, n√§chstes Jahr zu heiraten** - Nous pr√©voyons de nous marier l'ann√©e prochaine
- **Ich w√ºnsche mir eine Familie mit dir** - Je souhaite avoir une famille avec toi
- **Ich hoffe, wir werden viele Abenteuer erleben** - J'esp√®re que nous vivrons de nombreuses aventures

<PhraseOfDay
  word="Eines Tages werden wir auf all das zur√ºckblicken und l√§cheln"
  translation="Un jour nous regarderons tout cela en arri√®re et nous sourirons"
  pronunciation="[A√è-ness TA-guess V√àR-deune vir aof al dass tsou-RUK-bli-keune ount L√à-cheulne]"
  context="Une belle fa√ßon de relativiser les difficult√©s du moment"
/>

## Le futur ant√©rieur (pour les perfectionnistes)

L'allemand a aussi un futur ant√©rieur avec **werden + participe pass√© + haben/sein**. C'est rare √† l'oral, mais utile √† comprendre.

**Structure :** werden + participe pass√© + haben/sein

- **Bis morgen werde ich alles erledigt haben** - D'ici demain j'aurai tout termin√©
- **In zehn Jahren werden wir viel erlebt haben** - Dans dix ans nous aurons v√©cu beaucoup de choses

## Exercices pratiques pour couples

### Exercice 1 : Vos projets pour la semaine

Planifiez votre semaine ensemble en allemand. Alternez pour proposer des activit√©s :

- **Am Montag werden wir...** - Lundi nous allons...
- **Am Dienstag gehen wir...** - Mardi nous allons...
- **Am Wochenende...** - Le week-end...

### Exercice 2 : R√™ves √† long terme

Chacun votre tour, partagez un r√™ve en utilisant le futur :

**Questions guides :**
- Wo werden wir in zehn Jahren leben? (O√π vivrons-nous dans dix ans ?)
- Was werden wir zusammen erleben? (Que vivrons-nous ensemble ?)
- Wie werden wir unser Leben gestalten? (Comment fa√ßonnerons-nous notre vie ?)

### Exercice 3 : Promesses romantiques

√âcrivez trois promesses pour votre partenaire en utilisant le futur :

1. **Ich werde immer...** - Je vais toujours...
2. **Ich werde nie...** - Je ne vais jamais...
3. **Wir werden zusammen...** - Nous allons ensemble...

<VocabCard
  word="Ich verspreche dir"
  translation="Je te promets"
  pronunciation="[ich f√®r-CHPR√â-cheu dir]"
  example="Ich verspreche dir, dass ich immer f√ºr dich da sein werde."
/>

## Expressions idiomatiques sur l'avenir

| Allemand | Fran√ßais | Contexte |
|----------|----------|----------|
| Die Zeit wird es zeigen | Le temps nous le dira | Quand l'avenir est incertain |
| Wer wei√ü, was die Zukunft bringt | Qui sait ce que l'avenir r√©serve | Philosophique |
| Das Beste kommt noch | Le meilleur reste √† venir | Optimiste |
| Auf uns wartet eine gro√üe Zukunft | Un grand avenir nous attend | Motivant |

<CultureTip title="Pragmatisme allemand" flag="üá©üá™">
Les Allemands sont connus pour leur planification minutieuse. Ne soyez pas surpris si votre partenaire allemand veut discuter en d√©tail de vos projets futurs - c'est un signe d'engagement et de s√©rieux dans la relation !
</CultureTip>

## Erreurs courantes √† √©viter

1. **Oublier l'infinitif √† la fin** : En allemand, l'infinitif va toujours √† la fin
   - Correct : **Ich werde morgen kochen**
   - Incorrect : *Ich werde kochen morgen*

2. **Utiliser trop le futur avec werden** : Pr√©f√©rez le pr√©sent avec un indicateur de temps quand c'est naturel

3. **Confondre werden (futur) et wollen (vouloir)** :
   - **Ich werde gehen** = J'irai (futur)
   - **Ich will gehen** = Je veux partir (volont√©)

## Vos prochaines √©tapes

Maintenant que vous savez parler du futur en allemand, vous pouvez :
- Planifier vos sorties et voyages ensemble
- Partager vos r√™ves et aspirations
- Faire des promesses romantiques
- Discuter de vos projets de vie

L'avenir s'annonce radieux quand on le construit ensemble - et encore plus quand on peut en parler dans deux langues !

<CTA text="Continuez votre voyage linguistique ensemble" buttonText="Explorer plus de le√ßons" />

articles.title: Adjetivos Polacos: Concordancia y Uso
articles.content:
import VocabCard from '@components/VocabCard.astro';
import ConjugationTable from '@components/ConjugationTable.astro';
import CultureTip from '@components/CultureTip.astro';
import PhraseOfDay from '@components/PhraseOfDay.astro';
import CTA from '@components/CTA.astro';

Describir a tu pareja polaca con el adjetivo correcto no es solo romanticismo - es gram√°tica esencial. A diferencia del espa√±ol donde los adjetivos solo concuerdan en g√©nero y n√∫mero, los adjetivos polacos cambian seg√∫n g√©nero, n√∫mero Y caso. Suena aterrador, pero con los patrones correctos, pronto estar√°n dando cumplidos como hablantes nativos.

<PhraseOfDay
  word="Masz piƒôkne oczy"
  translation="Tienes ojos hermosos"
  pronunciation="mash PIENK-ne O-chi"
  context="Un cumplido cl√°sico donde 'piƒôkne' concuerda con 'oczy' (neutro plural)."
/>

## Por Qu√© Importa la Concordancia de Adjetivos

Imagina decirle a tu pareja que es guapo/a, pero usar la terminaci√≥n incorrecta. En polaco, dir√≠as:

- **Jeste≈õ przystojny** (eres guapo) - a un hombre
- **Jeste≈õ przystojna** (eres guapa) - a una mujer

Si mezclas estas terminaciones, no es solo inc√≥modo - cambia fundamentalmente el significado o hace que la oraci√≥n sea gramaticalmente incorrecta.

<VocabCard
  word="Piƒôkny/Piƒôkna/Piƒôkne"
  translation="Hermoso/Hermosa/Hermoso (neutro)"
  pronunciation="PIENK-ni / PIENK-na / PIENK-ne"
  example="To piƒôkne miejsce."
/>

## Los Tres G√©neros en Polaco

A diferencia del espa√±ol que tiene dos g√©neros, el polaco tiene tres:

| G√©nero | Ejemplo de Sustantivo | Adjetivo "bueno" |
|---|---|---|
| Masculino | **mƒô≈ºczyzna** (hombre) | dobr**y** |
| Femenino | **kobieta** (mujer) | dobr**a** |
| Neutro | **dziecko** (ni√±o) | dobr**e** |

<CultureTip title="Pista para el G√©nero">
Los sustantivos polacos a menudo revelan su g√©nero por la terminaci√≥n: la mayor√≠a de los sustantivos terminados en -a son femeninos, los que terminan en consonante suelen ser masculinos, y los terminados en -o o -e a menudo son neutros.
</CultureTip>

## Terminaciones de Adjetivos por G√©nero y N√∫mero

### Caso Nominativo (Caso B√°sico)

| G√©nero | Singular | Plural |
|---|---|---|
| Masculino | -y / -i | -i (personal) / -e (impersonal) |
| Femenino | -a | -e |
| Neutro | -e | -e |

**Ejemplos con "piƒôkny" (hermoso):**

- **piƒôkn-y mƒô≈ºczyzna** (hombre hermoso)
- **piƒôkn-a kobieta** (mujer hermosa)
- **piƒôkn-e dziecko** (ni√±o hermoso)
- **piƒôkn-i mƒô≈ºczy≈∫ni** (hombres hermosos - masculino personal)
- **piƒôkn-e kobiety** (mujeres hermosas)
- **piƒôkn-e dzieci** (ni√±os hermosos)

<VocabCard
  word="Wspania≈Çy/Wspania≈Ça/Wspania≈Çe"
  translation="Maravilloso/Maravillosa/Maravilloso (neutro)"
  pronunciation="vspa-NIA-ui / vspa-NIA-ua / vspa-NIA-ue"
  example="M√≥j wspania≈Çy partner."
/>

## Adjetivos que Terminan en -i vs -y

Los adjetivos que terminan en consonantes suaves (k, g) usan -i en lugar de -y:

- **drogi** (caro/querido) no ~~drogy~~
- **d≈Çugi** (largo) no ~~d≈Çugy~~
- **wysoki** (alto) no ~~wysoki~~

**Declensi√≥n de "drogi" (querido):**
- **drogi mƒÖ≈º** (querido esposo)
- **droga ≈ºona** (querida esposa)
- **drogie dziecko** (querido ni√±o)

## Adjetivos en Diferentes Casos

Los adjetivos deben concordar con los sustantivos no solo en g√©nero y n√∫mero, sino tambi√©n en caso. Aqu√≠ est√° el patr√≥n para los casos m√°s comunes:

### Caso Acusativo (Objeto Directo)

<ConjugationTable
  verb="piƒôkny"
  meaning="hermoso (terminaciones acusativas)"
  conjugations={[
    { person: "Masc. Animado", polish: "piƒôknego", english: "veo al hombre hermoso" },
    { person: "Masc. Inanimado", polish: "piƒôkny", english: "veo el carro hermoso" },
    { person: "Femenino", polish: "piƒôknƒÖ", english: "veo a la mujer hermosa" },
    { person: "Neutro", polish: "piƒôkne", english: "veo al ni√±o hermoso" },
    { person: "Plural Personal", polish: "piƒôknych", english: "veo a los hombres hermosos" },
    { person: "Plural Impersonal", polish: "piƒôkne", english: "veo los carros hermosos" }
  ]}
/>

**Ejemplos:**
- **Kocham piƒôkn-ƒÖ kobietƒô** (Amo a la mujer hermosa)
- **Widzƒô piƒôkn-y dom** (Veo la casa hermosa - masc. inanimado)
- **Spotykam piƒôkn-ego mƒô≈ºczyznƒô** (Conozco al hombre hermoso - masc. animado)

### Caso Genitivo (Posesi√≥n, "de")

- **Masculino/Neutro:** -ego (piƒôkn-**ego**)
- **Femenino:** -ej (piƒôkn-**ej**)
- **Plural:** -ych / -ich (piƒôkn-**ych**)

**Ejemplos:**
- **Oczy piƒôkn-ej kobiety** (Los ojos de la mujer hermosa)
- **Dom piƒôkn-ego mƒô≈ºczyzny** (La casa del hombre hermoso)

## Adjetivos Rom√°nticos Esenciales

Aqu√≠ hay adjetivos que usar√°n frecuentemente con su pareja:

| Masculino | Femenino | Neutro | Espa√±ol |
|---|---|---|---|
| **kochany** | **kochana** | **kochane** | amado/a |
| **ukochany** | **ukochana** | **ukochane** | querido/a |
| **cudowny** | **cudowna** | **cudowne** | maravilloso/a |
| **wspania≈Çy** | **wspania≈Ça** | **wspania≈Çe** | fant√°stico/a |
| **wyjƒÖtkowy** | **wyjƒÖtkowa** | **wyjƒÖtkowe** | excepcional |
| **uroczy** | **urocza** | **urocze** | encantador/a |

<VocabCard
  word="Moja ukochana ≈ºona"
  translation="Mi querida esposa"
  pronunciation="MO-ya u-ko-JA-na SHO-na"
  example="Moja ukochana ≈ºona jest najlepsza."
/>

## Errores Comunes a Evitar

### 1. Mezclar G√©neros
- ‚úÖ **M√≥j drogi mƒÖ≈º** (Mi querido esposo)
- ‚ùå **M√≥j droga mƒÖ≈º** (Terminaci√≥n femenina con sustantivo masculino)

### 2. Olvidar el Plural Personal
Para hombres en plural, usa la terminaci√≥n especial de "masculino personal":
- ‚úÖ **Wysoc-y mƒô≈ºczy≈∫ni** (Hombres altos)
- ‚ùå **Wysok-e mƒô≈ºczy≈∫ni**

### 3. Ignorar el Caso
Los adjetivos cambian con los casos:
- **Piƒôkn-a kobieta** est√° aqu√≠ (nominativo)
- Veo a **piƒôkn-ƒÖ kobietƒô** (acusativo)
- Los ojos de **piƒôkn-ej kobiety** (genitivo)

<CultureTip title="Consejo de Inmersi√≥n">
Escucha m√∫sica de amor polaca y presta atenci√≥n a c√≥mo los adjetivos cambian. Las canciones a menudo repiten frases con diferentes formas de adjetivos, lo que te ayuda a internalizar los patrones.
</CultureTip>

## Pr√°ctica con Descripciones de Pareja

Practiquemos describir a tu pareja:

**Para ella:**
- **Jeste≈õ piƒôkna** (Eres hermosa)
- **Masz cudownƒÖ osobowo≈õƒá** (Tienes una personalidad maravillosa)
- **Twoja urocza twarz** (Tu encantadora cara)

**Para √©l:**
- **Jeste≈õ przystojny** (Eres guapo)
- **Masz cudownƒÖ osobowo≈õƒá** (Tienes una personalidad maravillosa)
- **Tw√≥j uroczy u≈õmiech** (Tu encantadora sonrisa)

## Adjetivos con Preposiciones

Cuando los adjetivos siguen a preposiciones, cambian de caso:

- **z piƒôkn-ƒÖ kobietƒÖ** (con la mujer hermosa - instrumental)
- **dla piƒôkn-ej kobiety** (para la mujer hermosa - genitivo)
- **o piƒôkn-ej kobiecie** (sobre la mujer hermosa - locativo)

### Tabla de Referencia R√°pida para "dobry" (bueno)

| Caso | Masculino | Femenino | Neutro |
|---|---|---|---|
| Nominativo | dobry | dobra | dobre |
| Genitivo | dobrego | dobrej | dobrego |
| Dativo | dobremu | dobrej | dobremu |
| Acusativo | dobrego/dobry | dobrƒÖ | dobre |
| Instrumental | dobrym | dobrƒÖ | dobrym |
| Locativo | dobrym | dobrej | dobrym |

> **Consejo profesional:** No intentes memorizar todas las tablas de una vez. Comienza con nominativo y acusativo, ya que son los casos m√°s comunes en la conversaci√≥n diaria.

## Tu Siguiente Paso

La concordancia de adjetivos parece abrumadora al principio, pero recuerda que incluso los ni√±os polacos toman a√±os para dominarla perfectamente. Enf√≥cate en patrones que usar√°s m√°s frecuentemente - descripciones de tu pareja, su hogar compartido y sus actividades juntos.

Comienza con estas tres frases y pract√≠quenlas juntos:
1. **Jeste≈õ wspania≈Çy/wspania≈Ça** (Eres maravilloso/a)
2. **Mamy piƒôkny dom** (Tenemos una casa hermosa)
3. **Kocham tw√≥j uroczy u≈õmiech** (Amo tu encantadora sonrisa)


<CTA
  text="¬øListos para Dominar los Adjetivos Polacos?"
  buttonText="Empieza a Aprender"
/>

sections: ## Terminaciones de Adjetivos por G√©nero y N√∫mero

articles.title: Danish Weekend Activities Vocabulary for Couples
articles.content:
import VocabCard from '@components/VocabCard.astro';
import ConjugationTable from '@components/ConjugationTable.astro';
import CultureTip from '@components/CultureTip.astro';
import PhraseOfDay from '@components/PhraseOfDay.astro';
import CTA from '@components/CTA.astro';

Weekends in Denmark are sacred. It's time for couples to reconnect, explore, and embrace the famous Danish concept of "hygge." Whether you're strolling through Copenhagen, cycling along the coast, or enjoying a cozy movie night at home, knowing the right vocabulary will enrich your experience and help you plan activities together in Danish.

## Planning Your Weekend Together

Start the weekend conversation with these essential phrases:

<PhraseOfDay
  word="Hvad skal vi lave i weekenden?"
  translation="What shall we do this weekend?"
  pronunciation="vath skal vee LA-vuh ee WEEK-en-en"
  context="The perfect Friday evening conversation starter!"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Har du lyst til at...?"
  translation="Do you feel like...?"
  pronunciation="har doo lyst til at"
  example="Har du lyst til at g√• en tur i parken?"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Jeg foresl√•r..."
  translation="I suggest..."
  pronunciation="yai for-uh-SLAHR"
  example="Jeg foresl√•r at vi tager til stranden."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Det lyder hyggeligt!"
  translation="That sounds cozy/nice!"
  pronunciation="deh LY-ther HY-guh-leet"
  example="The perfect response to weekend plans."
/>

### Essential Planning Vocabulary

| Danish | Pronunciation | English |
|--------|---------------|---------|
| **Weekend** | WEEK-en | Weekend |
| **L√∏rdag** | L√òR-dai | Saturday |
| **S√∏ndag** | S√òN-dai | Sunday |
| **Ferie** | FEH-ree-uh | Vacation |
| **Fridag** | FREE-dai | Day off |
| **Planer** | PLA-ner | Plans |
| **Tid** | teeth | Time |
| **Sammen** | SAM-men | Together |

<CultureTip title="Danish Work-Life Balance" flag="üá©üá∞">
Denmark consistently ranks among the happiest countries, partly due to excellent work-life balance. Danes typically work 37 hours per week and fiercely protect their weekends. "Weekenden er hellig" (the weekend is sacred) is a common sentiment. Embrace this mindset together!
</CultureTip>

## Outdoor Activities

### Going for Walks

Danes love walking - it's perfect for couples and free!

<VocabCard
  word="Skal vi g√• en tur?"
  translation="Shall we go for a walk?"
  pronunciation="skal vee gaw en toor"
  example="A classic Danish activity suggestion."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="En g√•tur i skoven"
  translation="A walk in the forest"
  pronunciation="en GAW-toor ee SKO-ven"
  example="Lad os tage en g√•tur i skoven."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="At g√• langs stranden"
  translation="To walk along the beach"
  pronunciation="at gaw langs STRAN-en"
  example="Romantic and very Danish!"
/>

### Walking Vocabulary

| Danish | Pronunciation | English |
|--------|---------------|---------|
| **En tur** | en toor | A walk/trip |
| **At g√•** | at gaw | To walk |
| **Skoven** | SKO-ven | The forest |
| **Parken** | PAR-ken | The park |
| **Stranden** | STRAN-en | The beach |
| **S√∏en** | S√ò-en | The lake |
| **Havnen** | HOW-nen | The harbor |
| **Stien** | STEE-en | The path/trail |

### Cycling Adventures

Denmark is a cycling nation - perfect for active couples!

<VocabCard
  word="Skal vi cykle en tur?"
  translation="Shall we go for a bike ride?"
  pronunciation="skal vee SYK-luh en toor"
  example="Grab your bikes and explore together."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Lad os leje cykler"
  translation="Let's rent bicycles"
  pronunciation="lath os LAI-uh SYK-ler"
  example="Great for tourists in Copenhagen!"
/>

### Cycling Vocabulary

| Danish | Pronunciation | English |
|--------|---------------|---------|
| **Cykel** | SY-kel | Bicycle |
| **Cykelsti** | SY-kel-stee | Bike path |
| **At cykle** | at SYK-luh | To cycle |
| **Cykelhjelm** | SY-kel-yelm | Bike helmet |
| **Cykeltur** | SY-kel-toor | Bike trip |
| **Tandemcykel** | TAN-dem-sy-kel | Tandem bike |

<CultureTip title="Cycling Culture" flag="üá©üá∞">
Copenhagen has more bikes than people! Cycling is not just transportation but a lifestyle. Couple cycling is popular - you can rent a tandem bike for a fun experience. Just remember: always use hand signals and follow the bike lane rules!
</CultureTip>

## Water Activities

### Beach and Swimming

<VocabCard
  word="Lad os tage til stranden"
  translation="Let's go to the beach"
  pronunciation="lath os ta til STRAN-en"
  example="Perfect for a summer weekend."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Vil du med ud at bade?"
  translation="Do you want to come swimming?"
  pronunciation="veel doo meth ooth at BA-thuh"
  example="Invitation for a beach day."
/>

### Beach Vocabulary

| Danish | Pronunciation | English |
|--------|---------------|---------|
| **Strand** | stran | Beach |
| **Havet** | HA-vet | The sea |
| **At sv√∏mme** | at SV√òM-muh | To swim |
| **Badedragt** | BA-thuh-dragt | Swimsuit |
| **Badebukser** | BA-thuh-book-ser | Swim trunks |
| **Solcreme** | SOL-krem | Sunscreen |
| **H√•ndkl√¶de** | HAWN-klay-thuh | Towel |
| **Bades√∏** | BA-thuh-s√∏ | Swimming lake |

<VocabCard
  word="Vandet er koldt!"
  translation="The water is cold!"
  pronunciation="VAN-et air kolt"
  example="A common complaint at Danish beaches!"
/>

## Indoor Cozy Activities (Hygge Time)

### Movie and TV Nights

<VocabCard
  word="Skal vi se en film?"
  translation="Shall we watch a movie?"
  pronunciation="skal vee say en film"
  example="Classic cozy weekend activity."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Hvad med en serie?"
  translation="How about a series?"
  pronunciation="vath meth en SEH-ree-uh"
  example="For a proper binge-watching session."
/>

### Entertainment Vocabulary

| Danish | Pronunciation | English |
|--------|---------------|---------|
| **Film** | film | Movie |
| **Serie** | SEH-ree-uh | TV series |
| **Biografen** | bee-oh-GRA-fen | The cinema |
| **At streame** | at STREE-muh | To stream |
| **Popcorn** | POP-corn | Popcorn |
| **T√¶ppe** | TEP-puh | Blanket |
| **Sofa** | SO-fa | Couch |
| **Lys** | lyss | Candles |

<CultureTip title="Hygge at Home" flag="üá©üá∞">
Danish hygge is all about cozy atmosphere. For a true Danish movie night: light candles (lys), wrap up in blankets (t√¶pper), make hot chocolate (varm kakao), and snuggle on the sofa. This intimate atmosphere is the heart of hygge!
</CultureTip>

### Cooking Together

<VocabCard
  word="Lad os lave mad sammen"
  translation="Let's cook together"
  pronunciation="lath os LA-vuh math SAM-men"
  example="A romantic weekend activity."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Hvad skal vi lave til aftensmad?"
  translation="What shall we make for dinner?"
  pronunciation="vath skal vee LA-vuh til AF-tens-math"
  example="Start planning your meal together."
/>

### Cooking Vocabulary

| Danish | Pronunciation | English |
|--------|---------------|---------|
| **At lave mad** | at LA-vuh math | To cook |
| **At bage** | at BA-yuh | To bake |
| **K√∏kkenet** | K√òK-en-et | The kitchen |
| **Opskrift** | OP-skrift | Recipe |
| **Ingredienser** | in-greh-dee-EN-ser | Ingredients |
| **Morgenmad** | MOR-en-math | Breakfast |
| **Frokost** | fro-KOST | Lunch |
| **Aftensmad** | AF-tens-math | Dinner |

<VocabCard
  word="Du laver den bedste pandekager!"
  translation="You make the best pancakes!"
  pronunciation="doo LA-ver den BES-tuh PAN-uh-ka-yer"
  example="Compliment your partner's cooking!"
/>

### Game Nights

<VocabCard
  word="Skal vi spille et spil?"
  translation="Shall we play a game?"
  pronunciation="skal vee SPIL-luh et spil"
  example="Board game night suggestion."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Du snyder!"
  translation="You're cheating!"
  pronunciation="doo SNY-ther"
  example="Playful accusation during games."
/>

### Gaming Vocabulary

| Danish | Pronunciation | English |
|--------|---------------|---------|
| **Br√¶tspil** | BRET-spil | Board game |
| **Kortspil** | KORT-spil | Card game |
| **At spille** | at SPIL-luh | To play |
| **At vinde** | at VIN-nuh | To win |
| **At tabe** | at TA-buh | To lose |
| **Din tur** | deen toor | Your turn |
| **Terninger** | TAIR-ning-er | Dice |
| **Puslespil** | POOS-luh-spil | Puzzle |

## Exploring the City

### Museums and Culture

<VocabCard
  word="Lad os bes√∏ge et museum"
  translation="Let's visit a museum"
  pronunciation="lath os beh-S√ò-yuh et moo-SAY-om"
  example="Cultural date idea."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Er der en udstilling?"
  translation="Is there an exhibition?"
  pronunciation="air dair en ooth-STIL-ling"
  example="Ask about current exhibitions."
/>

### Culture Vocabulary

| Danish | Pronunciation | English |
|--------|---------------|---------|
| **Museum** | moo-SAY-om | Museum |
| **Kunstmuseum** | KOONST-moo-say-om | Art museum |
| **Galleri** | ga-luh-REE | Gallery |
| **Udstilling** | ooth-STIL-ling | Exhibition |
| **Teater** | teh-A-ter | Theater |
| **Koncert** | kon-SAIRT | Concert |
| **Festival** | fes-tee-VAL | Festival |

### Shopping Together

<VocabCard
  word="Skal vi g√• en shoppetur?"
  translation="Shall we go shopping?"
  pronunciation="skal vee gaw en SHOP-puh-toor"
  example="Weekend shopping trip."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Lad os kigge i butikkerne"
  translation="Let's browse the shops"
  pronunciation="lath os KIG-guh ee boo-TIK-er-nuh"
  example="Window shopping together."
/>

### Shopping Vocabulary

| Danish | Pronunciation | English |
|--------|---------------|---------|
| **Butik** | boo-TIK | Shop |
| **Indk√∏bscenter** | IN-k√∏bs-sen-ter | Shopping mall |
| **Marked** | MAR-keth | Market |
| **Loppemarked** | LOP-puh-mar-keth | Flea market |
| **At k√∏be** | at K√ò-buh | To buy |
| **At kigge** | at KIG-guh | To browse/look |
| **Gave** | GA-vuh | Gift |

<CultureTip title="Weekend Markets" flag="üá©üá∞">
Copenhagen has wonderful weekend markets! Torvehallerne is perfect for food lovers, while flea markets (loppemarkeder) are treasure troves for vintage finds. Exploring markets together is a quintessential Danish couple activity.
</CultureTip>

## Caf√© Culture

### Coffee Dates

<VocabCard
  word="Skal vi tage en kop kaffe?"
  translation="Shall we have a cup of coffee?"
  pronunciation="skal vee ta en kop KA-fuh"
  example="Danish coffee culture is strong!"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Kender du en god caf√©?"
  translation="Do you know a good caf√©?"
  pronunciation="KEN-er doo en go ka-FAY"
  example="Ask for recommendations."
/>

### Caf√© Vocabulary

| Danish | Pronunciation | English |
|--------|---------------|---------|
| **Caf√©** | ka-FAY | Caf√© |
| **Kaffe** | KA-fuh | Coffee |
| **Te** | tay | Tea |
| **Kage** | KA-yuh | Cake |
| **Wienerbr√∏d** | VEE-ner-br√∏th | Danish pastry |
| **Croissant** | krwa-SAN | Croissant |
| **Varm kakao** | varm ka-KA-oh | Hot chocolate |

<VocabCard
  word="Et stykke kage til at dele"
  translation="A piece of cake to share"
  pronunciation="et STYK-kuh KA-yuh til at DAY-luh"
  example="Romantic sharing is very Danish."
/>

## Sports and Fitness

### Active Weekends

<VocabCard
  word="Skal vi tr√¶ne sammen?"
  translation="Shall we work out together?"
  pronunciation="skal vee TRE-nuh SAM-men"
  example="Fitness date idea."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Lad os pr√∏ve yoga"
  translation="Let's try yoga"
  pronunciation="lath os PR√ò-vuh YO-ga"
  example="Suggest a new activity."
/>

### Sports Vocabulary

| Danish | Pronunciation | English |
|--------|---------------|---------|
| **At tr√¶ne** | at TRE-nuh | To exercise |
| **L√∏b** | l√∏b | Running |
| **Sv√∏mning** | SV√òM-ning | Swimming |
| **Yoga** | YO-ga | Yoga |
| **Fitness** | FIT-ness | Gym/Fitness |
| **Tennis** | TEN-nis | Tennis |
| **Fodbold** | FOTH-bolt | Football/Soccer |
| **Vandreture** | VAN-ruh-too-ruh | Hiking |

## Relaxation and Wellness

### Spa and Self-Care

<VocabCard
  word="Lad os slappe af"
  translation="Let's relax"
  pronunciation="lath os SLAP-puh a"
  example="Sometimes doing nothing is best."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Skal vi tage i spa?"
  translation="Shall we go to the spa?"
  pronunciation="skal vee ta ee spa"
  example="Treat yourselves to relaxation."
/>

### Relaxation Vocabulary

| Danish | Pronunciation | English |
|--------|---------------|---------|
| **At slappe af** | at SLAP-puh a | To relax |
| **Spa** | spa | Spa |
| **Massage** | ma-SA-shuh | Massage |
| **Sauna** | SOW-na | Sauna |
| **At sove l√¶nge** | at SO-vuh LENG-uh | To sleep in |
| **At l√¶se** | at LAY-suh | To read |
| **At hvile** | at VEE-luh | To rest |

<CultureTip title="Slow Weekends" flag="üá©üá∞">
Danes embrace slow living on weekends. "At sove l√¶nge" (sleeping in) on Sunday is practically a national tradition. Don't feel guilty about lazy mornings - it's part of the Danish art of living well together!
</CultureTip>

## Suggesting and Responding

### Making Suggestions

| Danish | Pronunciation | English |
|--------|---------------|---------|
| **Hvad med...?** | vath meth | How about...? |
| **Lad os...** | lath os | Let's... |
| **Jeg t√¶nkte p√•...** | yai TEN-tuh paw | I was thinking... |
| **Har du lyst til...?** | har doo lyst til | Do you feel like...? |
| **Kunne vi ikke...?** | KOO-nuh vee ik-kuh | Couldn't we...? |

### Responding Positively

| Danish | Pronunciation | English |
|--------|---------------|---------|
| **Ja, det lyder godt!** | ya, deh LY-ther got | Yes, that sounds good! |
| **Fedt!** | fet | Cool! |
| **Det vil jeg gerne!** | deh veel yai GAIR-nuh | I'd like that! |
| **Perfekt!** | per-FEKT | Perfect! |
| **Jeg gl√¶der mig!** | yai GLAITH-er mai | I'm looking forward to it! |

## Sample Weekend Conversations

### Friday Evening Planning
**Partner A:** "Hvad skal vi lave i weekenden, skat?"
**Partner B:** "Hmm, hvad med at tage til stranden l√∏rdag?"
**Partner A:** "Det lyder hyggeligt! Og s√∏ndag?"
**Partner B:** "Lad os slappe af hjemme med en film."
**Partner A:** "Perfekt! Jeg gl√¶der mig."

### Suggesting Activities
**Partner A:** "Har du lyst til at cykle en tur?"
**Partner B:** "Ja! Hvor skal vi hen?"
**Partner A:** "Vi kunne cykle langs havnen."
**Partner B:** "Fedt! Og bagefter tager vi en kop kaffe."
**Partner A:** "Aftale!"

## Your Perfect Danish Weekend

Now you have all the vocabulary to plan unforgettable weekends together in Danish. Whether you prefer active adventures or cozy indoor hygge, you can suggest, discuss, and enjoy activities using authentic Danish expressions.

Remember, the best part of learning these words isn't perfect pronunciation - it's the connection you build while using them with your partner. Start small: pick one activity each weekend and practice the relevant vocabulary. Before long, planning weekends in Danish will feel completely natural.

Ha' en god weekend sammen! (Have a good weekend together!)

<CTA text="Ready to plan your Danish weekend adventures?" buttonText="Start Learning Now" />

articles.title: Polish Negation: Say No Like a Native
articles.content:
import VocabCard from '@components/VocabCard.astro';
import ConjugationTable from '@components/ConjugationTable.astro';
import CultureTip from '@components/CultureTip.astro';
import PhraseOfDay from '@components/PhraseOfDay.astro';
import CTA from '@components/CTA.astro';

Mastering negation in Polish is crucial for expressing disagreement, setting boundaries, and having meaningful conversations with your Polish partner. Unlike English, Polish negation follows specific patterns that can seem tricky at first, but once you understand the rules, you'll sound much more natural.

<PhraseOfDay
  polish="Nie ma sprawy"
  english="No problem / Don't worry about it"
  pronunciation="nyeh ma SPRA-vee"
  context="A friendly way to say 'no big deal' when your partner apologizes or worries about something."
/>

## The Foundation: Nie

The word **nie** (no/not) is your gateway to Polish negation. It's placed directly before the word you want to negate, usually the verb.

<VocabCard
  polish="Nie"
  english="No / Not"
  pronunciation="nyeh"
  example="Nie rozumiem - I don't understand"
/>

### Basic Nie Patterns

**Nie** + verb creates the most common negative construction:

- **Nie kocham** (I don't love) - nyeh KO-ham
- **Nie m√≥wiƒô** (I don't speak) - nyeh MO-vyeh
- **Nie idƒô** (I'm not going) - nyeh EE-deh
- **Nie wiem** (I don't know) - nyeh vyem

<CultureTip title="Double Negatives Are Normal!">
Unlike English, Polish embraces double negatives. "Nie mam nic" (I don't have nothing) is perfectly correct and means "I have nothing."
</CultureTip>

## Saying "Never" with Nigdy

**Nigdy** (never) is more emphatic than simple **nie** and often appears with it for emphasis.

<VocabCard
  polish="Nigdy"
  english="Never"
  pronunciation="NEEG-dee"
  example="Nigdy ciƒô nie zapomnƒô - I will never forget you"
/>

### Romantic Uses of Nigdy

| Polish | English | Pronunciation |
|---|---|---|
| Nigdy ciƒô nie opuszczƒô | I will never leave you | NEEG-dee cheh nyeh o-PUSH-cheh |
| Nigdy nie k≈Çamiƒô | I never lie | NEEG-dee nyeh KWAH-myeh |
| Nigdy wiƒôcej | Never again | NEEG-dee VYEN-tsey |
| Nigdy nie my≈õla≈Çem | I never thought | NEEG-dee nyeh mee-SHWA-wem |

## Nothing, Nobody, Nowhere: Advanced Negation

### Nic (Nothing)

**Nic** (nothing) combines with **nie** to create emphatic negation:

- **Nie mam nic** (I have nothing) - nyeh mam neets
- **Nic nie m√≥wiƒô** (I'm not saying anything) - neets nyeh MO-vyeh
- **Nic nie rozumiem** (I don't understand anything) - neets nyeh ro-ZOO-myem

<VocabCard
  polish="Nic"
  english="Nothing"
  pronunciation="neets"
  example="Nic siƒô nie sta≈Ço - Nothing happened"
/>

### Nikt (Nobody)

- **Nikt nie przyszed≈Ç** (Nobody came) - neekt nyeh PSHEE-shed
- **Nie znam nikogo** (I don't know anybody) - nyeh znam nee-KO-go
- **Nikt tego nie wie** (Nobody knows this) - neekt TEH-go nyeh vyeh

### Nigdzie (Nowhere)

- **Nigdzie nie idƒô** (I'm not going anywhere) - NEEG-jeh nyeh EE-deh
- **Nie ma ciƒô nigdzie** (You're nowhere to be found) - nyeh ma cheh NEEG-jeh

## ≈ªaden: Not a Single One

**≈ªaden** (not a single/none) is an emphatic way to negate nouns. It changes form based on gender and case:

### Masculine Forms
- **≈ºaden mƒô≈ºczyzna** (not a single man) - ZHA-den mesh-CHEE-zna
- **≈ºadnego problemu** (no problem at all) - zha-NEH-go pro-BLEH-moo

### Feminine Forms
- **≈ºadna kobieta** (not a single woman) - ZHAD-na ko-BYEH-ta
- **≈ºadnej r√≥≈ºnicy** (no difference) - ZHAD-ney roozh-NEE-tsee

### Neuter Forms
- **≈ºadne dziecko** (not a single child) - ZHAD-neh JECH-ko

<CultureTip title="Emotional Emphasis">
Using ≈ºaden instead of simple nie adds emotional weight. "≈ªaden problem" sounds more reassuring than just "nie ma problemu."
</CultureTip>

## Common Negative Expressions for Couples

### Disagreeing Politely
- **Nie zgadzam siƒô** (I don't agree) - nyeh ZGAR-zam sheh
- **Nie sƒÖdzƒô** (I don't think so) - nyeh SOHNG-zeh
- **Nie jestem pewny/pewna** (I'm not sure) - nyeh YES-tem PEV-nee/PEV-na

### Setting Boundaries
- **Nie mogƒô** (I can't) - nyeh MO-geh
- **Nie chcƒô** (I don't want to) - nyeh htseh
- **Nie dzisiaj** (Not today) - nyeh JEE-shigh

### Expressing Emotions
- **Nie jestem szczƒô≈õliwy/szczƒô≈õliwa** (I'm not happy) - nyeh YES-tem shchesh-LEE-vee/shchesh-LEE-va
- **Nie podoba≈Ço mi siƒô** (I didn't like it) - nyeh po-do-BA-wo mee sheh
- **Nie martwiƒô siƒô** (I'm not worried) - nyeh MAR-tvyeh sheh

## Negating Past and Future Tenses

### Past Tense Negation
<ConjugationTable
  verb="Nie byƒá (not to be - past)"
  meaning="was/were not"
  conjugations={[
    { person: "I (m)", polish: "nie by≈Çem", english: "I was not" },
    { person: "I (f)", polish: "nie by≈Çam", english: "I was not" },
    { person: "You (m)", polish: "nie by≈Çe≈õ", english: "you were not" },
    { person: "You (f)", polish: "nie by≈Ça≈õ", english: "you were not" },
    { person: "He", polish: "nie by≈Ç", english: "he was not" },
    { person: "She", polish: "nie by≈Ça", english: "she was not" }
  ]}
/>

### Future Tense Negation
- **Nie bƒôdƒô** (I won't be) - nyeh BEN-deh
- **Nie zrobiƒô** (I won't do) - nyeh ZRO-byeh
- **Nie przyjdƒô** (I won't come) - nyeh PSHEE-deh

## Softening Negative Responses

Poles often soften negation to sound more polite:

### Using "Mo≈ºe" (Maybe)
- **Mo≈ºe nie dzisiaj** (Maybe not today) - MO-zheh nyeh JEE-shigh
- **Mo≈ºe nie teraz** (Maybe not now) - MO-zheh nyeh TEH-ras

### Using "Chyba" (Probably)
- **Chyba nie** (Probably not) - KHEE-ba nyeh
- **Chyba nie przyjdƒô** (I probably won't come) - KHEE-ba nyeh PSHEE-deh

## Common Mistakes to Avoid

### Don't Skip the Nie
In English, we can say "Never!" alone, but in Polish, you usually need both: **Nigdy nie!** (Never not!)

### Word Order Matters
Place **nie** immediately before the word you're negating:
- ‚úÖ **Nie kocham ciƒô** (I don't love you)
- ‚ùå **Kocham ciƒô nie** (incorrect word order)

### Gender Agreement
Remember that **≈ºaden** must agree with the gender of the noun it modifies:
- **≈ºaden mƒô≈ºczyzna** (masculine)
- **≈ºadna kobieta** (feminine)
- **≈ºadne dziecko** (neuter)

## Practice Scenarios for Couples

### Declining Plans
- **Nie mam czasu** (I don't have time) - nyeh mam CHA-soo
- **Nie mogƒô i≈õƒá** (I can't go) - nyeh MO-geh eeshch
- **Nie dzisiaj, kochanie** (Not today, darling) - nyeh JEE-shigh ko-HA-nyeh

### Expressing Preferences
- **Nie lubiƒô tego** (I don't like this) - nyeh LOO-byeh TEH-go
- **Nigdy nie jem miƒôsa** (I never eat meat) - NEEG-dee nyeh yem MYEN-sa
- **Nie jestem g≈Çodny/g≈Çodna** (I'm not hungry) - nyeh YES-tem GWOD-nee/GWOD-na

### Reassuring Your Partner
- **Nie martw siƒô** (Don't worry) - nyeh mar-tef sheh
- **Nie ma problemu** (No problem) - nyeh ma pro-BLEH-moo
- **Nigdy ciƒô nie zostawiƒô** (I'll never leave you) - NEEG-dee cheh nyeh zo-STA-vyeh

> Pro tip: Practice negation with everyday situations. Start with simple phrases like "Nie wiem" (I don't know) and gradually build up to more complex expressions.

Mastering Polish negation takes practice, but it's essential for expressing yourself authentically. Remember that Poles appreciate directness, so don't be afraid to use these negative forms when appropriate - they're a natural part of the language!


<CTA
  text="Ready to practice Polish negation with your partner?"
  buttonText="Start Learning Together"
/>

articles.title: 50 Italienska Dejtkv√§llsord f√∂r Par ‚Äì Romantiska Vocab f√∂r Era Perfekta Dates
articles.content:
import VocabCard from '@components/VocabCard.astro';
import ConjugationTable from '@components/ConjugationTable.astro';
import CultureTip from '@components/CultureTip.astro';
